reviewText: Amazing movie.  Mother Teresa was played real well.  I only wish this movie was done as a series.

As a Catholic nun I have to say that the person who motivated me to pursue a religious vocation other than my deep love of God was Mother Teresa.  She walked the walk.  There is no greater
sense of happiness in this world than to
be in the complete service of one's
neighbor.  Mother Teresa is a testament
to the latter and the movie is well done
In that it captures the essence of her
spirit and purpose.  A great movie for
the family in this age of self-gratification
and materialism.  A tribute to the real
meaning of life and an authentic religious vocation.  Thank you Mother Teresa.
Excellent film about the real Christian life.

Gives an insight into the life of Mother Teresa when she started, as well as the years where she did not hear God's voice, but continued in her work any way. Inspiring for all those who wonder where God is while they are working through tough tasks they have chosen to pursue, and who meet resistance along the way. This movie is not a Hollywood film, but that is what makes it so inspiring.

We are all aware of what a giant of the 20th century Mother Teresa became, what an inspiration she was to people of faith and of no faith, what a spiritual heroine she was. What this film portrays so convincingly is how it all began with one simple yes to God, without fanfare, support, monetary resources, planning, protection, approval from her own order, or even any clear idea of how things would work out. And what her letters reveal is that she carried out God's work for decades without even the ordinary divine consolation that prayerful people expect to receive from time to time. This kind of radical obedience to God is what will change the world. This is what the Church needs now more than ever.
I had no idea what a powerful influence she had.

The movie takes a look at the "dark night" that Mother Teresa underwent for 50 years. Her spiritual dark night was caused by being too close to Jesus, the light of the world. When you get too close to the light you are blinded. This was never known in her lifetime but discovered in letters and a diary after her death when the Vatican was looking into her cause for sainthood. A wonderful film that will have you crying with compassion.

It's "okay."  I own and have watched a number of documentaries and docudramas on Mother Teresa ...maybe four or five. This one was supposed to be about her letters to her Archbishop and spiritual director on her spiritual anguish based the book "Come Be My Light" or so I thought.  Unfortunately, there were only a handful of references to her letters!  I would have enjoyed hearing more quotations from those letters and seen more of her personal mental difficulties she faced regarding her faith in God.  I have read "Come Be My Light" and wish this movie was more faithful to it. Other than that, the movie did provide a brief overview of her vocation and I thought the actress who portrayed Mother did very good job.

"The Letters",  those written by Mother Teresa to her spiritual advisor brought to light a new dimension to this wonderful woman's life.  It exhibited her frailties through which she fought valiantly to continue her ministries to the forgotten and the poor.  The story exhibited the power of courage and determination despite hidden problems one might have.  I was immensely moved by this story.

Even though I am not Catholic, I profoundly enjoyed this movie. It shows Mother Teresa's heart for the poor, her battle against a closed religious system, her deflection of fame from herself to the poor, and the inner struggles of her soul.
I thought it was fascinating and really appreciated how, in the Catholic church, it appears that they reverence her higher for having had spiritual doubts and struggles, while in the Protestant church they tend to smear anyone who is not perfect or almost so.

This movie as an open and revealing story about Mother Teresa of Calcutta who will be named a saint in September 2016. The movie reveals her steadfast faith and special calling to the world's poor despite experiencing a spiritual desert for most of her life. Mother Teresa, I am, sure could be a challenge to people around her who were willing to live the status quo. She spoke the inconvenient truth of the sanctity of all life, from the womb to the tomb. She was small in stature but a giant in faith. She shows that becoming a saint is not for wimps.

This film elicited many tears from me.  I loved the following scenes the most:
1. When Mother Teresa sees the poor in the streets of Calcutta from the window of her convent, we can actually see her start to hear God's "call within the call."
2. When Mother Teresa treats one of her first dying patients, one of her assistants says there is no hope and that the man is dying.  Mother Teresa says that dying alone is such a fear and that this man can now die in our presence, among people who love him.
3. When Mother Teresa is treating a dying man inside her hospice, the man raises his head and utters,"Why are you doing this for me? I am Hindu."  She replies, "Because I love you, and I see Jesus Christ in you."
4. When Mother Teresa is tempted to go back to Loreto and abandon her mission to the poor, she puts her hand on the door of the convent and realizes she can't go back and must continue with her mission to the poor, despite the spiritual emptiness she feels.
5. Mother Teresas comment to the then radio reporter that she is merely a pencil in God's hand.
6. Mother Teresa's speech for the peace prize that includes the prayer of St Francis of Assisi: "Lord, make me a channel of your peace . . ."
This is an excellent film.

I am somewhat of a scholar on the life of Mother Teresa. This film is the best movie production I have seen depicting Mother Teresa. The BBC documentary of her life, Mother Teresa, is excellent also.  Juliette Stevenson portrays Mother Teresa in The Letters, nearly perfectly. Other actresses who have tried to be Mother Teresa have fallen short. Juliette captures Mother's mannerism, her speech patterns and even her walk. This is a must see.

I really enjoyed this film. I have to admit, I didn't expect a movie on the life of Mother Teresa to engage me but I found myself being inexplicably disarmed emotionally as I got further into it. The experience started to become about discovering the selflessness of this nun and her determination to keep pushing forward no matter what. It was very inspiring actually. By the end of the film, I was left thinking that I will never complain again about my lot in life! How rare it is that a human being literally gives up everything to help others!

It's a biography of someone who did not live a glamorous life, so the general public was harder on this movie than they should be.  The story is the historical background of Mother Teresa, and how her life became what it did.  She went through a lot of trials I never knew about.  I've watched it 3 times in one week, and found deeper levels to focus on each time.  It was an unusually quiet movie, so I'm glad I could hear the subtle statements I missed by wearing headphones on the third time.  That made a difference!  I enjoyed it, and I'm sure I will go back and watch it when I feel times are tough.  She was a blessing to many.

There are no words I can use to describe the power and influence this movie had on me. I have been going through dark times, having just lost a second parent and now being so alone in this world. I love mother Teresa's endurance, her courage and willingness to serve the poor. Her honesty about her loneliness, hardship and doubt really shook me to the core. We live in a society where we are constantly striving for happiness, success and appearances, when real peace comes when we are honest about our trials, darkness, loneliness and despair. I'm sure this movie doesn't do justice to the full life of mother Teresa but I am more interested in reading her letters and hearing from the heart of a woman who is a true testament to what Jesus said to do.

Wow I read some of these reviews and I truly think we must have watched different movies. Perhaps I need to watch it again only with the eye of a critic so I can see everything wrong that I seemed to have missed. But then that would be like reading all the ingredients in my chocolate after I ate it. The warm fuzzy feeling would be gone and I like the warm fuzzy feeling this movie left me with.
I loved The Letters. I especially loved the acting I think that Juliet Stevenson did an awesome portrayal of a woman that received a calling on her life that could not be ignored.  Granted the script could have used a little help. For instance the transitions in time between the then and now could have been a little better but that is just a little not enough to ruin the movie. The story is the main reason for watching The Letters, not the acting or cinematography. I think that most of the world was like me and really didn't realize how much sacrifice and anguish actually marked Mother Teresa life. Although ;the movie shows most of her life as a missionary it does demonstrate her twenty years of teaching and the political up hill battle she trod to be able to minister to the poor. Without the support of the local parish Mother Teresa had to battle day to day living. She had to demonstrate true love for the people, not a religious effort ,a showing or rather a demonstration of God's love to win over the very people she wanted to help. Teh movie follows her journey though the letters exchange with her mentor. I believe a truly inspirational film. .
The story of Mother Teresa was very interesting and how selfless she was about helping the poor and making sure they knew someone cared about them!!

beautiful and inspirational movie.
Wow, what an incredible soul.

We really enjoyed this movie. It tells a beautiful story of how a young nun, doing what she felt God wanted her to do as head mistress of the convent where she served in India, and then, as she witnessed the absolute poverty of those all around her, she felt the call of God to actually do more than pray for them. She knew God wanted her to be the hands and feet of Jesus to these people. And the world had a kingdom changer in the woman of Mother Teresa.
Love love love
Great movie

This is a great inspirational honor to Mother Theresa and all I can say is that for all of those lapse Catholics out there like myself it can serve as a renewal of faith. A wonderful film to a great lady.
This was a really great movie.

Wonderful, touching story of a woman who did not want the spotlight .... but only wanted to please God. Beautiful film - the best one I have seen to date on Mother Teresa and the Missionaries of Charity. Highly recommend.
Great story.  Shows her humanity and humility.
I loved it! It showed the life and the struggles of Mother Teresa's life! A must see!

I would recommend for anyone in ministry to watch this. This struggle is real, but obedience is real as well. Very inspiring!

Mother Teresa was a fraud who relished the pain and suffering of others. The millions funneled to the church through her "work" was spent on converting people rather than helping the sick.
Wonderful inspiring movie. It did just show how she started her own order. It showed how she came to start her path toward sainthood.

This film is simply inspiring and humbling.  It is an incredible tribute of an astounding life dedicated to finding Christ in the "least of these."  Through the epistles of Teresa we get a rare look into her person struggles to fulfill the vision she is sure the Lord has given, while simultaneously experiencing divine abandonment in a "dark night of the soul."  This film is also timely with the news released that Theresa will be sainted on September 4th, 2016.  The depth of story is complemented by high production values and superior acting.  It is a must-see for all persons of faith.

The movie shared a beautiful topic about one of the most selfless people to have ever lived, but unfortunately, the dialogue, content, scenery, acting, etc. were all more on par with a TV movie of the week type genre than a true mockumentary, which made the film neither inspiring nor interesting.  In short, this film simply doesn't do Mother Teresa justice.  It could have (and should have) been so much better.
What a beautiful movie, it brought tears to my eyes..a very recommended movie to all family and friends.
OLDER KID LIKE IT
Excellent movie! Makes one truly see humble and kind in full constant swing!

I PURCHASED THIS FOR MY NEIGHBOR WHO IS CATHOLIC.  I AM NOT CATHOLIC BUT LOVE THE STORY THAT WAS TOLD USING HER VERY OWN LETTERS. WHAT A WOMEN INDEED WHO LOVED JESUS CHRIST. WHAT A SACRIFICE SHE MADE AND HOW SHE DISTANCE HERSELF FROM THE CATHOLIC CHURCH TO DO GODS WILL.

Inspiring. So many things about Mother Teresa I didn't know. Glad the letters were not destroyed as she wanted because her story and life experience is a testament and inspiration to all who strive to be and do better in their life. You hear about saints and think they didn't have the daily struggles and challenges we all do, that they had a special connection with God during their life. Then you watch this movie and see the obstacles Mother Teresa over came only due to her strong faith in God. It makes her more human. She had her struggles and doubts just as we all do. She's an awesome role model.
Well made movie and love her example of loving others more than ourselves.
